questionListItems.title: After an organisation is registered as a charity, can the charity make changes to the disbursement plan & activities?

answer.body: Yes. However, they are required to update the Charities Unit/the relevant Sector Administrator if there are major changes to the activities and fund-disbursement plan.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What does the Certified Statement of Account refer to?

answer.body: The certified statement of accounts refers to the organisation’s Income and Expenditure Statements for the last 3 years. This is applicable for organisations that have been operating for at least 3 years.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Is there a fee charged for registering a charity?

answer.body: There is no fee for registering a charity under the Charities Act.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Can a CLG or Society register as a charity and whether the Memorandum of Association/Constitution will remain the same?

answer.body:
A CLG or Society set up for exclusively charitable purposes in Singapore must apply to register as a charity with the Commissioner of Charities/the relevant Sector Administrator within 3 months of its incorporation date.

The COC/SA will evaluate whether the organisation qualifies for charity status and if the M&AA or Constitution needs to be amended to meet the necessary requirements.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: How to submit a charity registration for an organisation (incorporated as a CLG/ Society)?

answer.body:
One of the personnel from the organisation can submit an online application by logging in to the Charity Portal using his/her Singpass which has been linked to the Corppass account.

 

***Please ensure that the Corppass Admin has granted the authorised Corppass user, the necesssary access rights to the Charity Portal on the Corppass website.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: How do I register a Trust as a charity?

answer.body:
The applicant may login to the Charity Portal (using his/her Singpass) and fill in the online application form to apply for charity status. The applicant should upload the trust deed as the governing instrument and select “Others” as its legal entity.

 

During the application for charity registration, the trust deed will be reviewed and an officer will inform you if amendments are required to meet the necessary requirements. If the trust is successfully registered, a UEN will be issued by the Office of the Commissioner of Charities.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: If a legal representative has been tasked to apply for new charity status on the Portal by organisation, must the firm attach an authorisation letter to show it has been permitted by the organisation to submit the application on their behalf?

answer.body:
A legal representative is not required to submit an authorisation form at the charity application stage. The applicant must ensure that the legal representative is the authorised Corppass User or authorised to transact on behalf of the organisation on the Charity Portal.

 

However, it is not recommended for a legal representative to submit the application as the contact person should ideally be someone from the charity itself.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What is the estimated timeline to process a charity application?

answer.body: The applicant should be notified of the outcome of the application within 90 days after the application has been submitted. This is based on the assumption that all required documents have been submitted and there are no further queries.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What specific guidelines do I have to note when naming a charity?

answer.body:
One of the considerations when assessing a charity application includes the use of specific words in the names for new set-ups that will only be allowed if the stipulated criteria are met. This is to prevent the misuse of some words that will convey the wrong impression to the public.

The organisation’s name cannot be:

  • Similar to an existing charity;

  • Misleading as to the true nature of the charitable purposes and activity to the public;

  • Containing offensive words; or

  • Entirely in a foreign language.

 

The organisation may contain the word:

  • “Singapore” or its abbreviation if it used within brackets at the end of its name, to indicate the place of registration;

  • “International” if the organisation has objects and activities serving beyond the community in Singapore; or

  • “Foundation” if the organisation is a self-funded by an individual, family or for-profit company to aid the organisation’s charitable purposes or be financed by an endowment.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What are the benefits of registering as a charity?

answer.body: All registered charities will enjoy automatic income tax exemption. For property which are used for exclusively charitable purposes, property tax may be exempted in full or partially upon application and reviewed by the Controller of Property Tax.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

answer.body:
Exempt charities are charitable institutions exempted from registration. They are:

 

  • Any university or educational institution, hospital or religious body established by an Act of Parliament; and

  • Any other institution which the Minister by order declares to be an exempt charity.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: How to apply for exempt charity status?

answer.body: The exempt charity framework has been phased out, and we will not be accepting any applications.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Is there a penalty for charities that don't register with the Commissioner of Charities / Sector Administrator?

answer.body: Yes. It is an offence under the Charities Act for organisations established for exclusively charitable purposes not to apply for charity registration. Such organisations should get in touch with CU or the Sector Administrator overseeing its respective sector to apply for registration as soon as possible.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: Can an organisation be both a VWO and a charity at the same time?

answer.body:
Yes, an organisation can be both a charity and a VWO (i.e. Voluntary Welfare Organisation). There is no legal definition of a VWO, and it typically refers to an organisation that provides welfare services and/or services that benefit the community at large and is not profit-making.

If the objects of the VWO are exclusively charitable and it meets the basic registration requirements, then it should apply for charity registration as well.

topics.title: Registering as a Charity in Singapore

questionListItems.title: What are the regulatory requirements that a large charity must adhere to with regard to the minimum number of board members?

answer.body: Regulation 4 of the Charities (Large Charities) Regulations specifies the requirement of a minimum of 10 governing board members in a large charity. In the instance where a large charity has fewer than 10 governing board members, it should notify the Sector Administrator immediately and to take such measures necessary to increase the number of its governing board members to not fewer than 10 within 6 months or within such time approved by the Sector Administrator. A large charity will only be exempted from such requirements if it is deemed fit by the Commissioner of Charities.
